result.title: Goal
result.description: Reduction of GHG emissions from energy use by rural and remote communities

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
Avoided annual GHG emissions from rural communities‚Äô energy use by end of project (EOP), ktCO2/year
Avoided GHG emissions from rural communities‚Äô energy use by end of project influence period, 10 years (EOPIP), ktCO2

result.title: Objective
result.description: Significantly accelerate the development of small-scale hydropower (SHP) by removing barriers through enabling legal and regulatory framework, capacity building and developing sustainable delivery models, thus substantially avoiding the use of conventional biomass and fossil fuels for power and other energy needs.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
No. of new small hydropower projects under implementation by EOP
Minimum No. of fully operational sHPPs by EOP
Annual electricity generation from newly installed sHPPs by EOP, MWh/yr
Cumulative electricity generation from newly installed SHPs by EOPIP, MWh/yr

actual.comment:
1 small hydropower plant with 30 kW of installed capacity is constructed and commissioned in Sorvo vilalge of Vahdat district. Total of 3 SHPPs with cumulative capacity of 245 kW are constructed and commissioned from the beginning of the project.
Manufacturing and construction of 4 small hydropower plants started. The total cumulative capacity of the foreseen plants is 475 kW.
1,288 MW/h/year
N/A

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: No. of operational demo/pilot SHP plants by EOP

actual.comment:
Total of 3 SHPPs have been constructed and commissioned, while 4 more SHPPs are in pipeline.
The total cumulative capacity of the constructed and commissioned SHPPs is 245 kW that annually generate 1,288 MW/h/year.
The 4 additional SHPPs that are in the pipeline will have a total cumulative installed capacity of 475 kW able to generate 2,460 MW/h/year of electricity.

target.comment: Conference on integrated rewable-energy based rural development organized by the end of Year 4

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Adapted and enhanced legislative and regulatory framework for small-scale hydropower development in the country.

baseline.comment: No regulations in support of RES Law

target.comment: Rules and regulations adopted by end of Year 1

actual.comment:
The legislative and regulatory frameworks for small scale hydropower development created in the previous years with the project‚Äôs support, the law on Renewable Energy Sources and the law on Energy efficiency and energy saving, have led the Government to adoption of strategic documents in favor of renewable energy development. As such the national programme for small hydropower plants construction was revised, and the national strategy for the development of renewable energy sources and energy efficiency is being developed. The revised national programme that will cover the period of 2015-2020 will include the small hydro, solar and wind energy sources, and during the reporting period the programme is being adopted.
Adopted sub-laws to the law on Renewable Energy Sources also regulate the conditions for the solar and wind energy sources, although the project does not directly aim at development of these sources. Nevertheless, the latest developments of renewables in the country suggest that combined application of renewable sources along with small hydropower would better address the issues with the lack of energy in the rural communities. The project has therefore been effective in communicating this message to the government, which was endorsed.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Enhanced technical and planning know-how and developed market chain for SHP in Tajikistan

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: % of the total SHP installed cost provided by locally made goods and services

actual.comment:
In line with the developed regulations for SHP development, the capacities to produce, maintain and operate SHPPs were created through the transfer of technology to beneficiary companies, Energoremont and Korgohi Mashinasozi, and through educating students at the Technical universities in Dushanbe and Kurgantyube. The local manufacturers‚Äô supported by the project have produced, tested and installed portable turbines, where the share of locally produced goods and services is estimated at over 50%. The companies are now engaged in the production and installation of electromechanical equipment for additional 4 SHPPs.
The human capacity of the technicians and experts in SHPP development and management is being built through the project. Annually, a total of 100 students from the technical universities are taking SHPP courses based on the modules developed with the project‚Äôs support.. To date 300 students have been reported to have received these courses at the Tajik Technical University and Kurgantyube Energy Institute.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Improved confidence on the technical and economic viability of integrated SHP-based rural development model

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: No. of SHP demos/pilots incorporating aspects of productive uses and livelihood support for host communities

target.comment: At least 5 community-owned SHP projects operate on a sustainable basis and at least 5 additional are under construction by the end of Year 4

actual.comment: Total of 3 community-owned SHPPs (Nurofar, Yazghulam and Sorvo) are operating on sustainable basis and 4 more are under construction. Sustainability of the constructed SHPPs is ensured through the introduced management mechanisms, fee collection methods, capacity building of the operators through trainings and provision of basic equipment. Additionally, SHPP Nurofar sells excess electricity to the local businesses (fuel station, dairy shop and the plastic windows production workshop) during the summer time based on contractual agreement. This measure allows the SHPP to operate on sustainable basis, as well as allowing the local businesses to have savings from the electricity bills. The national tariff for businesses is 33 dirams per kW (0.05 USD) whereas the SHPP offers a trade off electricity for 25 dirams per kW (0.038 USD).

result.title: Outcome 4
result.description: National Scaling-up Programme of Renewable Energy-based Integrated Rural Development

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Adopted and financed National Scaling-up Program

target.comment: Adopted and financed National Scaling-up Program by the end of Year 4

actual.comment:
Through continuous dialogue and political advice rendered to the government counterparts by the project and the international community operating in the energy sector, the Government has and is adopting a number of strategies in the energy sector, one of which is the National Strategy for Renewable Energy and corresponding action plans and national programmes. The programme and the strategies aim at scaling-up renewable energy based integrated rural development.
For instance, the government has already provided direct investments for SHP construction. In 2012 -2014 the amount invested by the Government cumulatively constituted USD 4.4 mln for 5 SHPPs with a total capacity of 1,967 kW. This investment has resulted in covering 1,500 households, schools, hospitals, as well as the business facilities and created employment for 200 people in remote rural areas of the country.

result.title: Output 1.1
result.description: Formulated, approved and enforced implementing rules and regulations (IRRs) of the new Law for RES that will facilitate actions geared towards the enhancement of the market environment for SHP

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
Simplified procedures and principles for the licensing and construction of SHP facilities
National RE/EE Fund

baseline.comment:
RES Law includes a number of provisions to facilitate investment in grid-connected RE projects, but they are not operationalized
National RE/EE Fund

target.comment:
Procedures adopted and enforced by end of Year 1
National RE/EE Fund set-up and is operational by end of Year 2

actual.comment:
A permanent inter-institutional working group for the implementation of the law "on energy saving and energy efficiency" and elaboration of proposals to implement the law has been established. Inter-institutional working group has 3 sub-groups responsible for: (i) issues related to establishment of Trust Fund for RES and EE; (ii) development of the National Strategy on RES and National energy saving program; and (iii) development of legal acts. The group is chaired by the Ministry of energy and water resources.
The charter of the Trust Fund has been revised to best meet the current developments in the renewable energy sector and was endorsed by 5 ministries except for the Ministry of Finance. The financial part of the trust fund still remains unresolved due to the lack of financial commitments from the main international institutions operating in the country that were considered as the primary source of funds along with the national contributions. It has to be mentioned however that the share of the national contribution remains unknown and requires further discussions.

result.title: Output 1.2
result.description: Central and local government institutions with enhanced capacities to develop and coordinate SHP projects.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: # staff members from relevant central and local government institutions trained in developing and coordinating SHP projects

target.comment: 30 staff members trained by the end of Year 2

actual.comment: In addition to the trainings carried out by the project for the Government representatives during the previous reporting year, the capacity assessment of the Ministry of Energy and Water Resources staff was conducted. It has been revealed that there is a significant gap in the planning of RES projects, especially in the financial and economic analysis of the SHPP projects, which creates a barrier for adequately managing and coordinating resources expanded for the construction of SHPPs. In this regard, the project in cooperation with EU Sustainable Energy Programme for Central Asia (CASEP), and direct involvement of the project‚Äôs Chief Technical Adviser, organized 3-days trainings on ‚ÄúCreating and managing the SHPP cadastre‚Äù, ‚ÄúBusiness game: Practical development of RES projects‚Äù and ‚ÄúFinancial and economic analysis of SHPP projects‚Äù which have helped to increase the capacity of 45 staff of the Ministry of Energy and Water Resources and Barki Tojik (the national electricity utility company).

result.title: Output 2.1
result.description: Guidebook on technical and policy aspects of SHP project development (to be used in all trainings to be delivered by the project)

target.comment: Guidebook on SHP project development prepared and disseminated by the end of Year 1

result.title: Output 2.2
result.description: Local workshops and manufacturers with enhanced capacities to install, construct, manufacture and repair SHP system equipment and components

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Technology transfer and capacity development plan prepared for selected local manufacturers

target.comment: 2 technology transfer and capacity development plan prepared by the end of Year 1

actual.comment:
The capacities of the local manufacturers (Energoremont and Korgohi Mashinasozi) to design, manufacture, construct, install and repair the SHP systems are further enhanced. The local manufacturers have received additional sets of needed equipment for the production of the SHPPs that include electronic and mechanical tools and equipment.
Under the supervision and direct coaching of the technology transfer deliverer, the local manufacturers have mastered the production of the portable turbines (2 x 15 kW) that were installed and commissioned on a pilot basis. Based on this experience, the manufacturers have been prepared for the manufacturing, construction, installation and repair of larger electromechanical equipment for SHPPs. Both manufacturers are now able to produce turbines and set into operation SHPPs of ranging capacities from 1 kW to 1,000 kW.

result.title: Output 2.3
result.description: Vocational training program for technicians involved in SHP design/construction and O&M

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: # of technicians annually undertaking vocational training on SHP

target.comment: 20 technicians annually undertaking vocational training on SHP starting from Year 2

actual.comment:
The project has signed a Memorandum of Understanding with the Tajik-Technical University to provide vocational trainings to technicians involved in SHP production. Based on the signed MoU the project has helped the university in developing the vocational training modules and provided IT equipment (a laptop, overhead projector and a screen). In August 2014, 3-day vocational trainings for 18 technicians from Vahdat district and 7 representatives of the Ministries of Energy of Tajikistan and Kyrgyzstan were held. The practical trainings were carried out on the facilities of Energoremont and Korgohi Mashinasozi with which the University has agreements..
In September 2014, the OSCE office in Dushanbe has requested the services of the University to educate 15 technicians in Rasht valley.

result.title: Output 2.4
result.description: Local manufacturers capable of producing combined electric and biomass-fired heating and cooking devices for rural households

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: # of local craft workshops capable of manufacturing and assemblage of simple, efficient and low-cost electric heating and cooking devices

target.comment: At least 1 local craft workshops by the end of Year 3

actual.comment: A Project study on the viability of producing the combined electrical and biomass fired heating and cooking device indicates that production of the devices locally will not be sustained: a) Local power supplies of 1 kW will not be sufficient to operate the device reducing its demand; and b) limited demand for these devices is expected due to the flooding of less expensive Chinese goods. The target is to be cancelled based on the recommendations of the Mid-Term Review.

result.title: Output 3.1
result.description: Technical studies, political commitments and institutional framework secured for pilot SHP projects

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
Feasibility studies
Number of integrated district development
Number of SHP projects in the pipeline

target.comment: FS for 2 sites by end of Year 1, 3 sites - by end of Year 2, 5 sites - by end of Year 3. IDDP for 2 districts by end of Year 2, 3 districts - by end of Year 3, At least 5 further SHP projects identified and construction started (without direct project support)

actual.comment:
The feasibility studies have been completed in the previous reporting period.
The IDDPs for 5 districts have been reviewed and updated accordingly.
5 SHPPs with a total capacity of 1,967 kW was constructed by the Government. Additionally, OSCE has supported the construction of 2 micro SHPPs (10 kW each) in Rasht Valley. IFC has signed an agreement with the Ministry of Energy and Water Resources for the construction of 18 MW hydropower plant in Zervashan valley. The Japan Government funded ‚ÄúLivelihoods Improvement in Tajikistan-Afghanistan Cross border Areas‚Äù (LITACA) project implemented by UNDP finances construction of 2 SHPPs in Shurabad and Jilikul districts. The electromechanical equipment for these two SHPPs (175 kW and 100 kW) will be produced by the local manufacturers supported by the project.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
Number of PPAs signed for purchase of power from pilot SHP plants by EOP
Number of local business supported in pilot localities

target.comment: At least 2 by the end of Year and 5 by the end of Year 4

actual.comment: The operation of the two commissioned pilot SHPPs in Burunov and Yazghulom are sustained by regular monitoring and provided technical support to the operators responsible for the operation-maintenance and management of the plants. The operators of these plants have been educated through the vocational trainings and have been supplied with the maintenance tools and equipment. The SHPP in Yazghulam that provides electricity to the border outpost on the Tajik-Afghan border is sustained by the technicians serving in the border post. The plant in Burunov on the other hand provides electricity to a number of clients including the households and the social and economic facilities, and has been connected to the national grid. Both SHPPs are operating in a sustainable manner.

result.title: Output 4.1
result.description: Project results asessed, analyzed and compiled into comprehensive national report

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Project results and Lessons learnt report

target.comment: Project results and Lessons learnt report prepared by end of Year 4

result.title: Output 4.3
result.description: Approved and funded proposal for national scaling up of the SHP demos/pilots

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Annual amount of governmental incentives allocated to support investment in new SHP plants under the scale-up plan by EOP, in USD

actual.comment: Considering the recommendations and policy advice of the project, in 2012 ‚Äì 2014 the Government has provided direct investments in SHPPs construction that cumulatively constitutes USD 4.4 mln for 5 SHPPs. The total capacity of the commissioned SHPPs is 1,967 kW.
